title: Module-3-Assignment
contents:
# Name: Skylar Walsh
# Professor: Lingyao Li
# Course: LIS4273.002
# Date: 2/1/2025



# Define two sets of data
firstSet <- c(10, 2, 3, 2, 4, 2, 5)
firstSet

[1] 10  2  3  2  4  2  5

secondSet <- c(20, 12, 13, 12, 14, 12, 15)
secondSet

[1] 20 12 13 12 14 12 15

# A1.
# "Central Tendency"
# Solve the mean, median, and mode of both data sets
# First set mean:
mean(firstSet)

[1] 4

# First set median:
median(firstSet)

[1] 3

# First set mode:
Mode(firstSet)

[1] 2
attr(,"freq")
[1] 3

# Second set mean:
mean(secondSet)

[1] 14

# Second set median:
median(secondSet)

[1] 13

# Second set mode:
Mode(secondSet)

[1] 12
attr(,"freq")
[1] 3

# A2.
# "Variation"
# Compute the range, interquartile, variance,
# and standard deviation for both sets.
# First set min and max:
firstSetMinMax <- range(firstSet)
firstSetMinMax

[1]  2 10

# First set range:
firstSetRange <- max(firstSet) - min(firstSet)
firstSetRange

[1] 8

# First set quartiles:
quantile(firstSet)

  0%  25%  50%  75% 100% 
 2.0  2.0  3.0  4.5 10.0 

# First set interquartile range:
IQR(firstSet)

[1] 2.5

# First set variance:
var(firstSet)

[1] 8.333333

# First set standard deviation:
sd(firstSet)

[1] 2.886751

# Second set min and max:
secondSetMinMax <- range(secondSet)
secondSetMinMax

[1] 12 20

# Second set range:
secondSetRange <- max(secondSet) - min(secondSet)
secondSetRange

[1] 8

# Second set quartiles:
quantile(secondSet)

  0%  25%  50%  75% 100% 
12.0 12.0 13.0 14.5 20.0 

# Second set interquartile range:
IQR(secondSet)

[1] 2.5

# Second set variance:
var(secondSet)

[1] 8.333333

# Second set standard deviation:
sd(secondSet)

[1] 2.886751

# A3.
# "Comparison"
# Compare results between the first and second set by
# discussing the differences between the two sets.
summary(firstSet)

   Min. 1st Qu.  Median    Mean 3rd Qu.    Max. 
    2.0     2.0     3.0     4.0     4.5    10.0 

summary(secondSet)

   Min. 1st Qu.  Median    Mean 3rd Qu.    Max. 
   12.0    12.0    13.0    14.0    14.5    20.0 

# Although both sets have the same range, standard deviation,
# variance, and interquartile range, they have a different
# mean, which will affect the coefficient of variance.
# Coefficient of variation as percent:
# First set:
sd(firstSet)/mean(firstSet)*100

[1] 72.16878

# Second set:
sd(secondSet)/mean(secondSet)*100

[1] 20.61965

# Because the first set has a larger coefficient of variation...
# the data is spread away from the mean on a larger interval.

title: Module 2 Assignment
description: The myMean function calculates the mean.
contents:
# Name: Skylar Walsh
# Professor: Lingyao Li
# Course: LIS4273.002
# Date: 1/24/2025

# The variable assignment2 has a vector with a total of 9 elements
assignment2 <- c(6, 18, 14, 22, 27, 17, 22, 20, 22)

# Define a function called myMean that will calculate the average
# of a vector. In the body of the function, we are adding all of
# the elements from the assignment2 variable and then dividing by how many
# items are in assignment2
myMean <- function(assignment2) {return(sum(assignment2)/length(assignment2))}

# Run the function, print the mean result into the console.
myMean(assignment2)

[1] 18.66667

title: My LIS4273 Blog
description: This is for LIS4273 advanced stats.
